awd_titl_txt: CAREER: III: Modeling the Heterogeneity of Heterogeneity: Algorithms, Theories and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Many high-impact data mining applications exhibit the co-existence of multiple types of heterogeneity, such as different classification tasks, different data sources, and different labeling oracles. It has broad applicability such as fraud detection, manufacturing, transportation, healthcare, etc. This project aims to answer two fundamental questions: (Q1) how to jointly model multiple types of heterogeneity? (Q2) how to theoretically characterize the model generalization performance? It is expected to advance the algorithmic and theoretical foundations of state-of-the-art data mining techniques limited to a single type of heterogeneity and the sparse literature on modeling dual heterogeneity. The resulting algorithms and theories will be assimilated into new curriculum development and multiple K-12 outreach activities. It could benefit various real applications where multiple types of heterogeneity co-exist. A close collaboration with industrial partners promises timely and measurable impacts on two application domains, including security and manufacturing.

In particular, this project strives to develop a unified, overarching data mining framework, with three complementary research thrusts. The first thrust creates a suite of effective and efficient algorithms for modeling the co-existence of multiple types of heterogeneity. The key idea is to introduce a joint regularizer on the parameter space to model the interplay among different types of heterogeneity. The second thrust theoretically characterizes the model generalization performance, especially how it is affected by (1) the co-existence of multiple types of heterogeneity and (2) the violations to the underlying assumptions behind each type of heterogeneity. The third thrust systematically evaluates the algorithms and theories from the first two thrusts on real applications. More details can be found at: http://faculty.engineering.asu.edu/jingruihe/lab-2/projects/heterogeneous-learning/.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to model and understand the Heterogeneity of Heterogeneity (HoH) in data mining, i.e., the co-existence of multiple types of data heterogeneity. HoH is commonly seen in a variety of high-impact real applications, such as manufacturing processes (e.g., heterogeneous tools and chambers, heterogeneous impacts of multiple steps in the manufacturing process on the product quality), abnormal user detection (e.g., heterogeneity information types, heterogeneity abnormal user patterns), etc. State-of-the-art techniques are rich in handling a single type of heterogeneity and are often inadequate in addressing HoH. This project fills in this critical gap by studying: (1) how to jointly model multiple types of data heterogeneity, and (2) how to theoretically understand the model generalization performance in the context of HoH.

During the entire project period, the PI's team has made significant contributions towards the three proposed thrusts, namely (Thrust 1) HoH-Algorithms, (Thrust 2) HoH-Theories, and (Thrust 3) HoH-Applications. 

For Thrust 1, the PI's team created a suite of effective and efficient algorithms for modeling HoH, especially the interplay among multiple types of data heterogeneity. In particular, they proposed novel techniques for various learning settings in the presence of HoH, including clustering, self-supervised learning, semi-supervised learning, active learning, and supervised learning. They studied various types of data, including data with feature representations, graph data, and time-evolving data. The key finding is that explicitly modeling the interplay among multiple types of data heterogeneity can lead to significantly improved performance, as measured by accuracy, robustness, regret, etc.

For Thrust 2, the PI's team theoretically characterized the performance of the proposed HoH-algorithms from Thrust 1, especially how it is affected by (1) the interplay of multiple types of heterogeneity and (2) the violations to the underlying assumptions behind each type of heterogeneity. They carried out the analysis in terms of the model generalization performance for domain adaptation regression and classification, the regret upper bound of contextual bandits with data heterogeneity, the computational complexity. They also proposed novel measures characterizing the data heterogeneity which are more applicable in real scenarios as compared to state-of-the-art. The key finding is that certain assumptions can greatly affect the model performance, such as the task relatedness assumption in the presence of task heterogeneity, and these assumptions should be carefully evaluated (e.g., with the proposed measures) before adopting the specific techniques for predictive modeling.

For Thrust 3, the PI's team evaluated the proposed algorithms and theories on real applications, including abnormal user detection and quality control in manufacturing processes. They used the proposed techniques and theoretical results for detecting abnormal users in the context of financial fraud detection with rich data such as graphs and time series; they also applied these techniques and results on manufacturing processes such as the aluminum smelting processes with multiple modalities and multiple resolution levels. The key finding is that explicitly modeling HoH can lead to higher detection rate as well as better interpretability in abnormal user detection, and improved quality control (lower error rate) in manufacturing processes.

The outcomes of this project include 70 publications, 9 tutorials, and 2 workshops at top-tier conferences such as ICML, ICLR, NeurIPS, KDD, as well as software packages that are available to the general public. They have also been integrated into the graduate-level course on data mining taught by the PI, which has been ranked as outstanding/excellent by the students. The project has partially supported 11 PhD students and 3 undergraduate students to advance their research agenda. The key findings have significantly advanced the understanding regarding the interplay of multiple types of heterogeneity, elucidated how such interplay can be effectively leveraged to greatly improve the performance of predictive modeling, and validated the huge potential of modeling HoH in multiple high-impact applications.
